study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of brief mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) as an adjunctive treatment for anxiety via telehealth during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that brief MBCT was feasible and acceptable, with high retention, good compliance, and significant improvements in mindfulness, self-compassion, and reductions in anxiety symptoms and transdiagnostic processes. Participants recommended extending the intervention beyond four sessions.
population_specificity: Patients with anxiety receiving telehealth treatment during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of CBT and third-wave CBT interventions in treating diabetes-related distress and their associative benefits on depression, anxiety, and glycaemic control.
results_summary: CBT significantly reduced diabetes-related distress and depression, while third-wave CBT significantly reduced anxiety. Neither intervention had a significant effect on glycated haemoglobin.
population_specificity: People with diabetes experiencing diabetes-related distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of response to psychological treatments, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, to inform personalized treatment selection for major depressive disorder.
results_summary: The study identified 74 predictors of response to various psychological treatments, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, but noted limitations due to methodological heterogeneities and publication biases.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective dose, optimal type, and most beneficial population for improving sleep with mindfulness-based movement (MBM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 61 RCTs showed that MBM significantly improved sleep quality, with long-term practice (more than twice per week for over three months and a total intervention time exceeding 24 hours) yielding the largest effects. Healthy populations and older adults benefited more than patients and younger adults.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, older adults, and patients with sleep disturbances.
effective_dosage: Practicing at least twice per week, with a total intervention time exceeding 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for alleviating symptoms of non-affective psychosis and to inform future clinical practice.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that short-term MBIs can be beneficial for non-affective psychosis, with no serious adverse events reported. The evidence supports the view that MBIs are particularly beneficial for young people.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-affective psychosis (schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including mindfulness, for reducing anxiety in individuals following myocardial infarction (MI).
results_summary: Among the psychological interventions reviewed, mindfulness was one of several approaches studied, with some studies reporting significant decreases in anxiety compared to usual care, while others showed no significant difference. The abstract does not isolate mindfulness-specific results, so its efficacy is inferred within the broader context of mixed findings.
population_specificity: Individuals who experienced myocardial infarction (MI) and reported anxiety.
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified for mindfulness alone)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness therapy improves sleep quality, cognition, and mental state in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and insomnia.
results_summary: Mindfulness significantly improved cognitive function, sleep quality, and reduced anxiety and perceived stress. EEG data showed significant changes in brainwave frequency bands associated with relaxation and attention during mindfulness practice.
population_specificity: Patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and insomnia (n=75).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on posttraumatic growth, perceived social support, and quality of life in breast cancer patients undergoing early chemotherapy.
results_summary: MBSR significantly increased levels of posttraumatic growth, perceived social support, and quality of life in breast cancer patients compared to routine care. The intervention demonstrated prominent validity in improving these psychological and social outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer in early chemotherapy (n = 101).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the measurement approaches used to assess outcomes of mindfulness-based interventions for mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and identify the most affected domains.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions improved coping, somatic symptoms, emotional symptoms, stress response, and cognitive domains (especially attention). Qualitative results suggested benefits across all domains, but biomarkers did not show significant changes.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness as a psychosocial intervention for schizophrenia compared to active controls, focusing on symptom reduction and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was superior to active controls at end-of-treatment for total symptoms in schizophrenia, though specific efficacy for secondary outcomes was not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness and/or relaxation-based interventions reduce stress, anxiety, and depression in parents with infants in the NICU.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness and relaxation interventions may effectively reduce anxiety symptoms in NICU parents, with moderate to large effect sizes, and show promise for depressive symptoms, but limited benefits for parental stress. Methodological weaknesses and heterogeneous factors hinder strong conclusions.
population_specificity: Parents with infants in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether outdoor mindful walking in nature could improve university students' sleep quality, mood, and mindfulness during the Covid-19 pandemic in the U.K.
results_summary: Both mindful walking in nature and walking in an urban environment significantly improved participants' trait mindfulness, sleep quality, and mood, but mindful walking in nature did not provide additional mental health benefits compared to urban walking.
population_specificity: University students in the U.K. during the Covid-19 pandemic

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine and synthesize the literature on mindfulness interventions in adolescents and young adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes or prediabetes to assess psychosocial and glycemic outcomes.
results_summary: Mindfulness was found to be an acceptable intervention for adolescents and young adults with type 1 diabetes and prediabetes, showing positive psychosocial and glycemic outcomes, though feasibility issues were noted. No studies evaluated mindfulness in type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults with type 1 diabetes or prediabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions as part of complementary and integrative medicine for managing behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSDs).
results_summary: The study found insufficient clinical evidence for mindfulness-based interventions in managing BPSDs, with mixed results or lack of sufficient data to draw definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Dementia patients with behavioral and psychological symptoms (BPSDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of the Eat Breathe Thrive (EBT) yoga-based program in preventing eating disorders and supporting embodiment through mindfulness skills.
results_summary: EBT participants showed significant reductions in eating disorder behaviors, depression, and emotional regulation difficulties, along with increased mindfulness skills like interoceptive awareness and mindful eating. Most benefits were sustained at 6-month follow-up, and participants reported immediate well-being improvements after a single session.
population_specificity: Community sample of 168 participants (93.5% women), aged 18-65, from the United States and United Kingdom.
effective_dosage: 2-hour sessions, once per week for 7 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of an unguided digital mindfulness-based self-help app (Headspace) in reducing stress among health care workers.
results_summary: The study found that Headspace led to small but statistically significant reductions in stress, depression, anxiety, and improvements in well-being, mindfulness, self-compassion, and compassion for others, but no significant effects on burnout, ruminative brooding, or sickness absence.
population_specificity: National Health Service staff in England (2182 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness intervention in improving the emotional state of women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness was more effective than the control group in reducing anxiety and depression in infertile women, with statistically significant but modest effect sizes (SMD = -0.31 for anxiety, SMD = -0.94 for depression).
population_specificity: Infertile women undergoing IVF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether exposure to green and blue spaces reduces the risk of anxiety and depression among young people aged 14-24 years living in urban settings and to provide a conceptual framework.
results_summary: The review found that walking or being in green spaces improves mood and state anxiety immediately after the intervention, with social interaction, physical activity, and mindfulness mediating the relationship between green space exposure and mental health. The absence of noise and restorative qualities of green spaces promotes mindfulness and interrupts rumination, reducing the risk of anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: Young people aged 14-24 years living in urban settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand adults' experiences with treatment-resistant mental health conditions in primary care and explore patient-driven recommendations, including mindfulness as a potential intervention.
results_summary: The study found that people with treatment-resistant mental health conditions often cycle through self-management, GP visits, and antidepressant use, suggesting mindfulness could help break this cycle when antidepressants fail.
population_specificity: Adults with treatment-resistant mental health conditions (anxiety, depression, panic disorder, PTSD, OCD) in primary care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether higher engagement with the Unwinding Anxiety app's educational modules and adjunctive features was associated with improvements in anxiety, worry, interoceptive awareness, and emotional regulation.
results_summary: Completing >75% of the program was linked to a 22.6-point increase in interoceptive awareness and an 11.6-point decrease in worry. Increased meditation use correlated with reduced anxiety scores, while stress meter use was associated with improved emotional regulation.
population_specificity: Adults with generalized anxiety disorder (primarily female, average age 42.9 years).
effective_dosage: Average completion of 20.2 out of 32 educational modules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a mindfulness-based stress reduction program in improving attentional control and reducing mind-wandering in older adults.
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of mindfulness for attentional control and mind-wandering, with secondary outcomes including improved cognition, emotion regulation, and inflammation markers, but final results are pending as it is a trial in progress.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65-85 years.
effective_dosage: Eight-week mindfulness program (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Eight weeks, with booster sessions every three months for 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the usability of a digital health (DH) solution and the feasibility of a DH intervention designed to promote emotional and mental wellbeing of caregivers of children undergoing growth hormone treatment (GHt).
results_summary: The study expects to capture significant data on the feasibility of the DH solution, including its effects on caregivers' distress, positive affectivity, mental wellbeing, self-efficacy, and children's quality of life and treatment adherence. Usability and engagement metrics will also be assessed.
population_specificity: Caregivers of children undergoing growth hormone treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and potential impact of a 5-week online positive affect skills intervention (LARKSPUR) that includes mindfulness among other techniques, for adults with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results regarding mindfulness specifically, as the study focuses on feasibility, acceptability, and secondary pain outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) (N = 90).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the theoretical model of self-compassion, its mental and physical benefits, and address common misconceptions about it.
results_summary: The study found that self-compassion, including mindfulness, is effective in improving mental and physical well-being and dispels myths about it being weak or selfish. Interventions like compassion-focused therapy and mindful self-compassion were discussed as productive approaches.
population_specificity: General population experiencing suffering or pain from personal or external challenges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an integrated childbirth education intervention, including mindfulness techniques, on reducing childbirth fear, anxiety, and depression, while improving dispositional mindfulness in pregnant women.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced fear of childbirth, anxiety, and depression, while increasing dispositional mindfulness compared to the control group, with effects sustained at 36 weeks gestation and 1 week postpartum.
population_specificity: Pregnant women ≥ 20 years of age with a singleton pregnancy (12-24 weeks gestation) and a fear of childbirth score ≥ 7, along with their support partners.
effective_dosage: 8-week course including mindfulness breathing, body scans, stretching, sitting meditation, and mindfulness walking (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of different interventions, including mindfulness therapy, on mental health outcomes in autistic people.
results_summary: The study found that some forms of mindfulness therapy may be helpful for autistic people without intellectual disability, but further research is necessary. The trials did not report long-term effects or efficacy for those with intellectual disability.
population_specificity: Autistic people, specifically those without intellectual disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher specificity of psychoeducational content improved perceptions of the acceptability and credibility of mindfulness-based programs (MBPs) as a mental health intervention.
results_summary: Participants exposed to general psychoeducation endorsed higher acceptability scores for MBPs, while credibility scores improved post-psychoeducation regardless of specificity. The study suggests psychoeducation enhances public perceptions of MBPs.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of psychological therapies and mind-body techniques, including mindfulness, in managing common dermatologic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based interventions were among the most promising psychological therapies for managing skin diseases, alongside cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal therapy. The analysis included 40 articles with 3112 patients, showing positive outcomes in conditions like psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Individuals of all ages with dermatologic diseases, including psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, vitiligo, pruritus, acne vulgaris, and acne excoriée.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of mental health treatments, including mindfulness, for depression symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The review found immediate positive effects of mindfulness and other mental health treatments for depression in COVID-19 patients, though methodological limitations affected generalizability. Only two studies included follow-up assessments, and long-term efficacy remains unclear.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with depression symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of mindfulness-based therapies in treating insomnia in peri- and post-menopausal women and assess their impact on secondary outcomes.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation and relaxation for insomnia showed promise, but long-term effects remain unknown. The study noted improvements in mood and functional outcomes but lacked comprehensive data on sustained benefits.
population_specificity: Peri- and post-menopausal women with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of psychological therapies, including mindfulness, on pain intensity, disability, and psychological distress in individuals with chronic painful temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to draw reliable conclusions about mindfulness specifically, as most data focused on CBT. CBT showed small benefits in reducing pain intensity at follow-up and psychological distress compared to alternative treatments, but not against control.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 12 years and over with painful TMD lasting 3 months or longer.
study_duration: Varies by study, with the shortest being 4 weeks and follow-up ranging from 3 to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online self-help intervention based on Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) for cancer survivors with chronic painful chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN), comparing guided and unguided versions to a waiting list control.
results_summary: The study will assess pain interference as the primary outcome, along with secondary outcomes like psychological distress, quality of life, and mindfulness skills, but results are not yet reported as the trial is ongoing. Qualitative interviews will explore user experiences and satisfaction post-treatment.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors with painful CIPN lasting at least 3 months, who completed chemotherapy at least 6 months prior.
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week self-management course with 6 modules).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of interdisciplinary pain management, including mindfulness, on pain-related disability and opioid reduction in polymorbid pain patients with multiple psychiatric conditions.
results_summary: Veterans in the interdisciplinary pain program reported significantly greater decreases in pain-related disability compared to usual care at post-treatment and follow-ups, but no difference was found in opioid use reduction between groups.
population_specificity: 103 military veterans with moderate-to-severe pain-related disability, depression, anxiety, and/or PTSD, all with recent persistent opioid use and high comorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on symptoms (insomnia, depression, fatigue, paresthesia) and emotional competencies in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Both ACT and MBSR led to reduced symptoms (medium to large effect sizes) and improved emotional competencies (large effect size) in MS patients, with no significant difference between the two interventions at study-end.
population_specificity: 76 individuals with MS (81.6% female; mean age 38.88 years; EDSS median 2; range 0-5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how mindfulness can enhance a surgeon's performance, mindset, interactions, and execution based on recent scientific advancements and evidence.
results_summary: The study found that regular mindfulness practice decreases burnout rates, reduces medical errors, improves sleep, and enhances surgical performance. It suggests mindfulness as a valuable tool for surgeons and physicians to manage stress and improve overall performance.
population_specificity: Surgeons, physicians, and medical professionals, particularly those in high-stress, fast-paced environments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness therapy (MT) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for pain relief and quality of life improvement in patients with diabetic neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness therapy significantly improved pain severity, quality of life, and depressive symptoms in patients with painful diabetic neuropathy, with sustained benefits in pain interference and depressive symptoms after follow-up. However, long-term effects require further verification.
population_specificity: Patients with painful diabetic neuropathy (PDN)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of mindfulness meditation training (MMT) on the functional connectivity between large-scale brain networks (DMN, SN, CEN).
results_summary: The study found increased functional connectivity between the default mode network (DMN) and salience network (SN), as well as between the SN and central executive network (CEN), after one month of MMT, suggesting improved interconnectivity among these networks.
population_specificity: Healthy, meditation-naïve adults (N = 46).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions with a meditation component in reducing anxiety symptoms in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based meditation interventions led to a reduction in anxiety symptoms in older adults post-intervention, regardless of the specific intervention used. The results were based on seven randomized controlled trials involving 355 participants.
population_specificity: Older adults with anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and synthesize qualitative experiences of participants with depression who took part in Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT).
results_summary: Participants reported benefits such as increased awareness, perspective, and agency, as well as acceptance towards their experiences, self, and others. However, there was variability and ambivalence regarding expectations and difficulties within mindfulness practices.
population_specificity: Individuals with current or previous depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of shame and guilt in trauma recovery among asylum-seekers and whether a mindfulness- and compassion-based intervention could mediate these effects.
results_summary: The study found that shame, but not guilt, mediated the associations between traumatic stress exposure, postmigration difficulties, and posttraumatic stress. The mindfulness-based intervention showed therapeutic effects on trauma recovery through its impact on shame.
population_specificity: 158 Eritrean asylum-seekers (55.7% female) in an unstable high-risk urban postdisplacement setting in Israel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness yoga intervention could improve anxiety in children with school refusal.
results_summary: The study developed a mindfulness yoga program tailored for schoolchildren and planned to evaluate its impact on anxiety using the Spence Children's Anxiety Scale-Children. The program was designed to be engaging for children to practice daily.
population_specificity: Children aged 10-15 years with school refusal.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program distributed on DVD, frequency implied as daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) versus general health education (HT) on HIV management and mindfulness in adolescents and young adults living with HIV (AYALH).
results_summary: MBSR participants showed greater increases in medication adherence post-program compared to HT, though baseline mindfulness was higher in the MBSR group. The study collected data on mindfulness, medication adherence, HIV viral load, and CD4 levels at multiple time points.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (13-24 years old) living with HIV, predominantly non-Hispanic Black (92%), with 51% male, 46% female, and 3% transgender.
effective_dosage: Nine sessions (specific duration or frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Data collected at baseline, post-program (3 months), 6 months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of third-wave cognitive behavioral therapies, including mindfulness and acceptance interventions, for improving mental health in adults with epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness and acceptance interventions, such as Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy, outperformed wait-listed controls or usual care, though individual treatment responses varied. Mental health benefits were observed but were not consistent across all participants.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic epilepsy (941 participants across 11 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on interventions, including mindfulness, to improve mental health and wellbeing in college and university students.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions were found to be effective compared to passive controls, with evidence supporting their ability to reduce common mental health difficulties in students. The effects of mindfulness were noted to be more enduring than psychoeducation interventions.
population_specificity: Post-secondary students attending colleges or universities in high-income OECD countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based training (MBT), adaptive cognitive training (aCT), and a waitlist control on emotion regulation strategies in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and examine cognitive functioning as a moderator.
results_summary: The MBT group used acceptance strategies more frequently post-training compared to aCT and waitlist groups, but there were no differential effects on maladaptive strategies, cognitive reappraisal, or success of acceptance use. Cognitive functioning did not moderate treatment gains.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a remote yoga-based mindfulness intervention (eMMB) compared to an empathic attention control in women undergoing surgery for suspected gynecologic malignancy.
results_summary: The study found that eMMB was feasible and showed improvements in pain intensity postoperatively, warranting further efficacy studies. Participation rates were 43% among eligible patients.
population_specificity: Women undergoing surgery for suspected gynecologic malignancy.
study_duration: Perioperative timeframe (assessed at baseline, weeks 2 and 4 postoperatively)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neural mechanisms of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) in reducing pain response compared to active and waiting list controls, as well as long-term meditators.
results_summary: MBSR showed significant reductions in neural pain response (NPS) compared to the active control group and pre-post intervention, with modest effects on subjective pain unpleasantness. Long-term meditators reported lower pain but did not differ in neural response, while intensive retreat practice correlated with reduced SIIPS1.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (N=115) and long-term meditators (N=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and acceptability of mindfulness-informed interventions (MBIs) for stroke survivors and their family caregivers, as well as their potential benefits in managing stroke-related consequences.
results_summary: The study found that MBIs are feasible and acceptable for stroke populations and may serve as an important complementary treatment to help manage psychological distress, functional deficits, and cognitive impairment. However, research on MBIs in stroke care is still in early stages, and further tailored studies are recommended.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors and their family caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether mindfulness-based therapy for insomnia (MBTI) could reduce discrepancies between subjective and objective sleep parameters in older adults compared to a sleep hygiene, education, and exercise program (SHEEP).
results_summary: MBTI significantly reduced sleep onset latency discrepancy and improved sleep perception, correlating with better sleep quality and reduced insomnia symptoms. No significant change was observed in wake after sleep onset discrepancy for either intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults with sleep disturbances

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a CBT-based weight management intervention, including mindfulness, could improve or sustain executive functioning and related brain activity in individuals with obesity or overweight.
results_summary: The intervention group showed greater accuracy on executive function tasks (Flanker and Stroop) and modest improvements in neural markers compared to controls, along with significant weight loss (-7.1 pounds vs. +1.0 pounds). The study provides preliminary evidence that a multicomponent CBT-based intervention can help sustain executive function over 4 months.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity or overweight

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions in mitigating psychological consequences (e.g., anxiety, depression, stress) during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Mindfulness and meditation-based interventions significantly reduced anxiety in 90.9% of RCTs and depression in 83.3% of RCTs, demonstrating effectiveness in alleviating psychological distress. The interventions were standardized and showed high reliability and validity in outcome measures.
population_specificity: General population, healthcare workers, and patients with COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of positive psychology interventions, including mindfulness, on well-being and mental health across Arab countries.
results_summary: PPIs, including mindfulness, appeared effective for promoting well-being and reducing mental health issues, though some risks of bias were noted. Cultural adaptation was mentioned but lacked detail.
population_specificity: Adults (73%) and healthy populations (86%) from 10 Arab countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a Dialectical Behaviour Therapy (DBT) protocol for relatives of individuals with BPD versus the same protocol plus a mindfulness component (DBT-M).
results_summary: Both interventions led to significant improvements in most tested variables, but only the DBT-M group showed statistically greater improvement in negative attitudes towards the illness.
population_specificity: Relatives of individuals diagnosed with borderline personality disorder (BPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether an app-based mindfulness intervention (MBI) could improve smoking abstinence rates compared to a psychoeducation control during a scheduled quit attempt.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results, but the study tests the hypothesis that an app-based MBI will outperform a psychoeducation control in increasing smoking abstinence in a geographically diverse sample.
population_specificity: Adults who currently smoke cigarettes and are willing to make a voluntary quit attempt, recruited from all 58 counties in California.
effective_dosage: Two 10-minute sessions per day for 14 days (total 280 minutes).
study_duration: 14 days preceding a planned quit date.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the development strategy of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and its role in advancing Process-Based Therapy (PBT) and the Extended Evolutionary Meta-Model (EEMM) for evidence-based psychological interventions.
results_summary: The study identified 72 replicated measures that successfully mediated intervention outcomes in mental health, highlighting the utility of idiographic and functional approaches in psychological therapy. The EEMM framework effectively summarized these findings, suggesting a shift toward personalized, process-based interventions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on psychological interventions for mental health outcomes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effects of an mHealth nutrition education and mindful snacking intervention for weight loss and improved dietary practices among Chinese adolescents with overweight, including whether implementation intention formation improved outcomes.
results_summary: The study developed a 3-week mindful eating intervention delivered via 10 smartphone videos and found preliminary evidence of feasibility and potential benefits for weight management and dietary practices, though specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Chinese adolescents with overweight (n=55, age=16.35±0.48 years, BMI=25.79±2.05 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy adapted for GAD (MBCT-A) was noninferior to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy adapted for GAD (CBT-A) in treating anxiety symptoms and other related outcomes.
results_summary: MBCT-A was found to be noninferior to CBT-A in reducing anxiety symptoms, with no significant differences between the two groups at the 3-month follow-up. Both interventions showed long-term benefits, and no severe adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adult patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) (n=138).
study_duration: 8 weeks of treatment, with follow-up assessments at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-week hybrid Mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) in reducing caregiver stress and improving well-being for caregivers of patients with dementia over a 6-month follow-up.
results_summary: The study proposes a hybrid MBI model with potential advantages such as lower duration, easier access, and longer follow-up. It plans to measure physiological indicators and qualitative feedback to assess effectiveness, though specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Caregivers of patients with dementia recruited from three local NGOs.
effective_dosage: 6 weekly 90-minute group-based sessions (hybrid face-to-face and online).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether anxiety sensitivity is a potential mechanism for the impact of mindfulness training on anxiety and depression.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in anxiety sensitivity and overall anxiety severity and impairment, with marginally significant reductions in depression severity and impairment. Anxiety sensitivity mediated the effects of mindfulness training on anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: Participants with high psychological distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of psychological interventions, including mindfulness, in fostering resilience, improving mental symptoms, and promoting well-being in nurses.
results_summary: The study found moderate effects of resilience training, including mindfulness, on resilience and well-being at post-intervention, with sustained short-term benefits for well-being and delayed benefits for anxiety and stress. No significant effects were found for depression, anxiety, and stress immediately post-intervention.
population_specificity: Nursing staff exposed to chronic work-related stressors.
study_duration: Short-term (≤3 months) follow-up noted, but exact intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory and immune-modulating potentials of yoga, along with its role in reducing risk for immune dysfunction and impaired mental health during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that yoga can bolster innate immunity, inhibit cytokine release syndrome, improve mental health by alleviating anxiety and depression, and provide cardioprotective effects. It also highlighted yoga as a safe, nonpharmacological intervention with multiple health benefits.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for COVID-19 patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based supportive psychotherapy on posttraumatic growth, resilience, and self-compassion in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based supportive psychotherapy significantly increased posttraumatic growth, resilience, and self-compassion in cancer patients, with moderate to large effect sizes, and these improvements were maintained at follow-up.
population_specificity: Cancer patients referred to a cancer prevention and control center in Isfahan, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current state and methodological quality of mixed methods research (MMR) in complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), including mindfulness interventions.
results_summary: Among the 17 medical studies analyzed, mindfulness intervention was one of the areas studied, with 76% of pilot studies using MMR to assess feasibility. The majority of studies were rated as good in quality, though some lacked detailed reporting on integration and justification for mixed methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (general CAM research context, including mindfulness).
